results.title: Island people
results.creator_credit: Philip Leacock, John Taylor and Realist Film Unit (Great Britain)
results.brief_description:
How Six People Spend Saturday: “It is Saturday in Britain, the day divided between work and rest. In the morning six people, representative of various types, are seen at work in the industrial areas, on the farms and in the cities. They are a craftsman from the Midlands, a typist in a big Manchester office, a tug captain on the River Thames, a farmer from the Lowlands of Scotland, a woman doctor from Cardiff and a small boy who lives in a suburb.
At midday the people crowd out of offices, factories and schools, all going home to prepare for the half-holiday.
Saturday afternoon is set aside for enjoyment. Out they go to their games and amusements, to play football and hockey, rugby and running, to work in the garden, to walk in the woods. At the end of the afternoon they go out to various places of amusement, or they return home to read and play or to make clothes or model aeroplanes.” (Source: Films of Britain - British Council Film Department Catalogue - 1940)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Philip Leacock, John Taylor and Realist Film Unit (Great Britain)

results.title: Hollywood Costume. Inside the wardrobe: panel discussion
results.creator_credit: Kim Montgomery, Richard Greenhalgh, Sam Mapplebeck and ACMI

video_links.name: Hollywood Costume. Inside the wardrobe: panel discussion

results.brief_description:
This panel discussion explores the collaborative process between film director and costume designer, the link between costume and character and how costumes connect audiences with on-screen worlds. It also focuses on the artistic role of costuming in the filmmaking process.

Hear from leaders in costuming, film and fashion, the influential Australian film and television costumers Edie Kurzer (‘South Solitary’, ‘Look Both Ways’, ‘Matching Jack’) Cappi Ireland (‘I Frankenstein’, ‘Animal Kingdom’, ‘The Slap’) and Anna Borghesi (‘Mao’s Last Dancer’, ‘Ned Kelly’ ,’Romper Stomper’) in a discussion chaired by NIDA’s Head of Costume, Fiona Reilly.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Kim Montgomery, Richard Greenhalgh, Sam Mapplebeck and ACMI

results.title: Hollywood Costume: Deborah Nadoolman Landis interview
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, Kim Montgomery, Sam Mapplebeck and ACMI

video_links.name: Hollywood Costume: Deborah Nadoolman Landis interview

results.brief_description:
Professor Deborah Nadoolman Landis, an Oscar nominated Hollywood costume designer (‘Raiders of the Lost Ark’, ‘Blues Brothers’, Michael Jackson’s ‘Thriller’) is the author of ‘Hollywood Costume’ (2012), the prize-winning catalogue for the exhibition, and ‘Hollywood Sketchbook: A Century of Costume Illustration’ (2012) among many other volumes. Landis received her Ph.D. from the Royal College of Art in London and is the Founding Director of the David C. Copley Center for Costume Design at the UCLA School of Theater, Film and Television.
In this interview she talks about the origins of the Hollywood Costume industry, working as a costume designer, what a costume designer does and the relationship between the director and the costume designer.

results.title: I've been everywhere
results.creator_credit: Rob Flisher, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Robert Flisher was excited to leave Australia and see the world as it was his childhood dream to join the Navy. Flisher opens up about his experiences with the Navy and talks about some of the exciting places he visited during his service.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rob Flisher, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: A Life on the farm
results.creator_credit: Oz Sanderson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Oz Sanderson grew up on his farm with his two brothers during the Great Depression. His dad signed a consent form for him to join the army. While Oz was determined to serve as a pilot, the farm was always in his heart and he was more than happy to return to it after the war ended.

results.title: Survivor
results.creator_credit: Oz Phillips, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: At 18, Oswald enlisted in the Army through the Scotch College Cadet Force. He served in Darwin for two and a half years, surviving 76 raids, before training for inventory and being sent to Borneo to engage the Japanese. He can only recall the experience with “fear, fright and exhilaration”. Declared unfit for military service, he took some time to feel better again before marrying in 1950.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Oz Phillips, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: The St Arnaud boys
results.creator_credit: Norm Michael, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Norm started his life in the Army with six other local boys from his local area. He really enjoyed the mateship and sense of community he shared with them, and reminisces on the good times they had over the years. The mateship still lives on today when Norm catches up with them back in their home town, St Arnaud.

results.title: We kept them flying
results.creator_credit: Maude Coates, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: On the way home from enrolling in the Women’s Australian Auxiliary Air Force (WAAAF) in 1941, Maude Coates learnt that the Japanese forces had just bombed Darwin. For almost 4 years, Coates worked hard and built a great sense of companionship with the other women she lived and worked with. Serving time in the Women’s Forces out of duty, Maude feels proud to have served her country and been part of history.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Maude Coates, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Land and sea
results.creator_credit: Keith Payne, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Keith Payne had a terrible acne problem when he was a youngster but it only got worse when he was deployed into the tropics. Unfortunately for Payne, his attempts to sign up to volunteer in Japan were shot down when the doctors looked at his acne and sent him home.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Keith Payne, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: The Wind beneath their wings
results.creator_credit: Gwen Hancock, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: As a shy country girl, Gwen joined the Air Force when she was 18 years old and was posted at several locations around Victoria. Becoming a dressmaker after she was discharged from the army, Gwen married and lived life on a farm where she cultivated brown sheep, Shetland ponies and goats.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gwen Hancock, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

Becoming a dressmaker after she was discharged from the army, Gwen married and lived life on a farm where she cultivated brown sheep, Shetland ponies and goats.
